responses: A cherry angioma is a bright cherry-red skin growth that is usually small, ranging from pinhead size to about one quarter inch (0.5 centimeter) in diameter. It can appear smooth or may stick out from the skin.

patterns: Most children with chickenpox have the following symptoms before the rash appears: Fever Headache Stomach ache The chickenpox rash occurs about 10 to 21 days after coming into contact with someone who had the disease. In most cases, a child will develop 250 to 500 small, itchy, fluid-filled blisters over red spots on the skin. The blisters are most often first seen on the face, middle of the body, or scalp. After a day or two, the blisters become cloudy and then scab. Meanwhile, new blisters form in groups....
responses: If you suspect that a child is in immediate danger due to abuse or neglect, it is important to take immediate action. You can call 911 or the local emergency number to report the situation. Additionally, you can contact the Childhelp National Child Abuse Hotline at 1-800-4-A-CHILD (1-800-422-4453). This hotline is available 24/7, and crisis counselors can provide guidance and support. They can help you determine the necessary steps to ensure the child's safety. It's important to note that all calls are anonymous and confidential. If you are in need of assistance in a language other than English, interpreters are available in over 170 languages. Remember, it is crucial to report any suspected cases of child abuse or neglect to protect the well-being of the child.

patterns: The main symptoms of chigger bites are: Severe itching Red pimple-like bumps or hives Itching usually occurs several hours after the chiggers attach to the skin. The bite is painless. A skin rash may appear on the parts of the body that were exposed to the sun. It may stop where the underwear meets the legs. This is often a clue that the rash is due to chigger bites.
responses: The main symptoms of chigger bites include severe itching, red pimple-like bumps or hives, and a skin rash that may appear on the parts of the body that were exposed to the sun. The itching usually occurs several hours after the chiggers attach to the skin, and the bite itself is painless. It is common for the rash to stop where the underwear meets the legs, which can be a clue that it is due to chigger bites. To alleviate the symptoms, you can try over-the-counter antihistamines such as Benadryl (diphenhydramine) to reduce itching and inflammation. Applying calamine lotion or hydrocortisone cream to the affected areas can also help relieve itching. Additionally, keeping the affected area clean and avoiding scratching can prevent secondary infections. If the symptoms persist or worsen, it is advisable to consult a healthcare professional for further evaluation and treatment.

patterns: WHAT YOU CAN DO TO HELP If you think a child is in immediate danger because of abuse or neglect, call 911 or the local emergency number. Call the Childhelp National Child Abuse Hotline at 1-800-4-A-CHILD (1-800-422-4453). Crisis counselors are available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. Interpreters are available to help in more than 170 languages. The counselor on the phone can help you determine what steps to take next. All calls are anonymous and confidential. Counseling and support groups are available for children and for abusive parents who want to get help.

The rash typically occurs about 10 to 21 days after coming into contact with someone who has the disease.  The chickenpox rash usually starts on the face, middle of the body, or scalp. patterns: Signs of physical abuse in a child include: Sudden change in behavior or school performance Alertness, watching for something bad to happen Acting out behavior Leaving home early, going home late, and not wanting to go home Fear when approached by adults Other signs include unexplained injuries or a strange explanation of injuries, such as: Black eyes Broken bones that cannot be explained (for example, infants who do not crawl or walk usually do not get broken bones) Bruise marks shaped like hands, fingers,...
responses: In men, chlamydia may cause symptoms similar to gonorrhea. These symptoms may include:  - Burning feeling during urination - Discharge from the penis or rectum - Tenderness or pain in the testicles - Rectal discharge or pain  In women, symptoms of chlamydia may include:  - Burning feeling during urination - Painful sexual intercourse - Rectal pain or discharge - Symptoms of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), such as abdominal pain, fever, and abnormal vaginal discharge - Vaginal discharge or bleeding after intercourse  It's important to note that not everyone infected with chlamydia will experience symptoms. If you suspect you may have chlamydia, it is recommended to get tested and treated. Treatment typically involves a course of antibiotics. Please consult with a healthcare professional for proper diagnosis and treatment plan.

As a doctor, I can provide some general information about the signs of physical abuse in a child. These signs may include:  1. Sudden change in behavior or school performance 2. Alertness, watchi...

patterns: Some common symptoms are: Difficulty urinating, which includes painful urination or burning during urination Discharge from the penis Redness, swelling, or itching of the opening of the urethra at the tip of the penis Swelling and tenderness of one or both testicles Chlamydia and gonorrhea often occur together. The symptoms of chlamydia infection may be similar to symptoms of gonorrhea, but they continue even after treatment for gonorrhea is finished.
responses: Yes, chlordiazepoxide is indeed found in medicines with names such as Librax and Librium. patterns: This poison can be found in: Bleach Used in a number of manufacturing processes Note: This list may not include all sources of chlorinated lime.
responses: Chlorinated lime, also known as bleaching powder, is a chemical compound that is commonly used as a disinfectant and bleaching agent. It is primarily used in water treatment, as well as in the textile, paper, and food industries. It is important to note that chlorinated lime should not be ingested or used without proper precautions, as it can be toxic. If you suspect poisoning or have any concerns, I recommend seeking immediate medical attention.

patterns: Chlorine is present in: Gas released when mixing bleach with some of the powdered cleansing products and ammonia (chloramine gas) Gas released when opening a partially filled industrial container of chlorine tablets that have been sitting for several months (for example, the first opening of a container after a pool has been closed all winter) Mild cleaners Some bleach products Swimming pool water (and tablets used in swimming pool water) Note: This list may not include all uses and sources of chlorine.
responses: Yes, chlorophyll can be found in various sources such as green plants, plant foods, some cosmetics, natural supplements, and other products. It is a pigment responsible for the green color in plants and plays a crucial role in photosynthesis.

patterns: Chlorpromazine is found in chlorpromazine hydrochloride. Other medicines may also contain chlorpromazine.
responses: Yes, that's correct. Chlorpromazine is the active ingredient found in chlorpromazine hydrochloride. It is an antipsychotic medication that is used to treat various mental health conditions such as schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. It works by affecting certain chemicals in the brain to help restore the balance of neurotransmitters. Other medications that may contain chlorpromazine include Thorazine and Largactil. It is important to note that the dosage and specific formulation of chlorpromazine may vary depending on the brand and the condition being treated.

patterns: Newborns generally prefer to breathe through their nose. Typically, infants only breathe through their mouths when they cry. Babies with choanal atresia have difficulty breathing unless they are crying. Choanal atresia may affect one or both sides of the nasal airway. Choanal atresia blocking both sides of the nose causes acute breathing problems with bluish discoloration and breathing failure. Such infants may need resuscitation at delivery. More than one half of infants have a blockage on only one side, which causes less severe problems. Symptoms include: Chest retracts unless the child is breathing through mouth or crying. Difficulty breathing following birth, which may result in cyanosis (bluish discoloration), unless infant is crying. Inability to nurse and breathe at same time. Inability to pass a catheter through each side of the nose into the throat. Persistent one-sided nasal blockage or discharge.
responses: When an older child or adult is choking, it is important to recognize the danger signs and act quickly. These danger signs include:  1. Inability to speak: If the person is unable to speak or make any sound, it may indicate a blockage in the airway.  2. Difficulty breathing: If the person is struggling to breathe or experiencing shortness of breath, it could be a sign of choking.  3. Noisy breathing or high-pitched sounds while inhaling: This can occur when air is trying to pass through a partially blocked ...

patterns: When an older child or adult is choking, they will often grab their throat with the hand. If the person does not do this, look for these danger signs: Inability to speak Difficulty breathing Noisy breathing or high-pitched sounds while inhaling Weak, ineffective coughing Bluish skin color (cyanosis) Loss of consciousness (unresponsiveness) if blockage is not cleared
responses: The danger signs of choking that you mentioned are indeed important to be aware of. If someone is experiencing choking, it is crucial to act quickly to clear the blockage. Here are some steps you can take to help someone who is choking:  1. Encourage coughing: If the person is conscious and able to cough, encourage them to continue coughing forcefully to try and dislodge the object.  2. Perform abdominal thrusts (Heimlich maneuver): Stand behind the person and place your arms around their waist. Make a fist...

responses: Choanal atresia is a condition where there is a blockage in one or both sides of the nasal airway in newborns. This can cause difficulty in breathing unless the baby is crying. If both sides of the nose are blocked, it can lead to acute breathing problems, bluish discoloration, and even breathing failure, requiring resuscitation at delivery.  On the other hand, if only one side of the nose is blocked, the symptoms are usually less severe. Some common symptoms of choanal atresia include:  1. Chest retraction...

responses: Acute cholecystitis is indeed a painful condition that can lead to chronic cholecystitis. The symptoms of acute cholecystitis can include:  - Sharp, cramping, or dull pain in the upper right or upper middle of your belly. - Steady pain lasting about 30 minutes. - Pain that spreads to your back or below your right shoulder blade. - Clay-colored stools. - Fever. - Nausea and vomiting. - Yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes (jaundice).  It is important to note that chronic cholecystitis may not always cause noticeable symptoms. However, if you are experiencing any of the symptoms mentioned above, it is advisable to seek medical attention for proper diagnosis and treatment.  Please keep in mind that I am not able to provide specific medical advice or prescribe medication without evaluating your condition in person. It would be best to consult with a healthcare professional for a proper diagnosis and treatment plan.

Impetigo: This is a bacterial infection that causes blisters or sores on the face. Treatment usually involves topical antibiotics such as mupirocin ointment or oral antibiotics like cephalexin...

intents.tag: Chronic motor or vocal tic disorder
patterns: A tic is a sudden, fast, repeated movement or sound that has no reason or goal. Tics can involve: Excessive blinking Grimaces of the face Quick movements of the arms, legs, or other areas Sounds (grunts, throat clearing, contractions of the abdomen or diaphragm) Some people have many kinds of tics. People with the condition can hold off these symptoms for a short time. But they feel relief when they carry out these movements. They often describe the tics as a response to an inner urge. Some say they have abnormal sensations in the area of the tic before it occurs. Tics may continue during all stages of sleep. They may get worse with: Excitement Fatigue Heat Stress
responses: Tics are sudden, fast, repeated movements or sounds that have no reason or goal. They can involve excessive blinking, grimaces of the face, quick movements of the arms, legs, or other areas, as well as sounds such as grunts, throat clearing, or contractions of the abdomen or diaphragm. Some people may experience multiple types of tics.  Individuals with this condition can temporarily suppress these symptoms, but they often feel relief when they carry out these movements. They may describe the tics as a resp...

patterns: Chronic myelogenous leukemia is grouped into phases: Chronic Accelerated Blast crisis The chronic phase can last for months or years. The disease may have few or no symptoms during this time. Most people are diagnosed during this stage, when they have blood tests done for other reasons. The accelerated phase is a more dangerous phase. Leukemia cells grow more quickly. Common symptoms include fever (even without infection), bone pain, and a swollen spleen. Untreated CML leads to the blast crisis phase. Bleeding and infection may occur due to bone marrow failure. Other possible symptoms of a blast crisis include: Bruising Excessive sweating (night sweats) Fatigue Fever Pressure under the lower left ribs from a swollen spleen Rash -- small pinpoint red marks on the skin (petechiae) Weakness
responses: Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) is indeed grouped into phases: chronic, accelerated, and blast crisis. During the chronic phase, which can last for months or years, individuals may have few or no symptoms. It is often diagnosed incidentally during routine blood tests.   In the accelerated phase, the disease becomes more dangerous as leukemia cells grow more quickly. Common symptoms during this phase may include fever (even without infection), bone pain, and a swollen spleen.   If CML remains untreated, i...

patterns: Symptoms of Hashimoto disease may include any of the following: Constipation Difficulty concentrating or thinking Dry skin Enlarged neck or presence of goiter, which may be the only early symptom Fatigue Hair loss Heavy or irregular periods Intolerance to cold Mild weight gain Small or shrunken thyroid gland (late in the disease)

It is characterized by inflammation of the thyroid gland, leading to an underactive thyroid or hypothyroidism.   Some of the symptoms of Hashimoto's disease include: - Fatigue - Weight gain - Constipation - Dry skin - Hair loss - Intolerance to cold - Enlarged neck or presence of goiter - Difficulty concentrating or thinking - Heavy or irregular periods i...

patterns: A child may have one or more birth defects and the severity can vary significantly. A cleft lip may be just a small notch in the lip. It may also be a complete split in the lip that goes all the way to the base of the nose. A cleft palate can be on one or both sides of the roof of the mouth. It may go the full length of the palate. Other symptoms include: Change in nose shape (how much the shape changes varies) Poorly aligned teeth Problems that may be present because of a cleft lip or palate are: Failure to gain weight Feeding problems Flow of milk through nasal passages during feeding Poor growth Repeated ear infections Speech difficulties
responses: The poisonous ingredients found in Clinitest tablets are copper sulfate and sodium hydroxide. These ingredients can be harmful if ingested in large amounts. It is important to keep these tablets out of reach of children and to follow the recommended dosage instructions. If you suspect that someone has ingested Clinitest tablets or any other product containing these ingredients, it is important to seek immediate medical attention.

patterns: People with cleidocranial dysostosis have a jaw and brow area that sticks out. The middle of their nose (nasal bridge) is wide. The collar bones may be missing or abnormally developed. This pushes the shoulders together in front of the body. Primary teeth do not fall out at the expected time. Adult teeth may develop later than normal and an extra set of adult teeth grow in. This causes the teeth to become crooked. Intelligence level is most often normal. Other symptoms include: Ability to touch shoulders together in front of body Delayed closure of fontanelles ("soft spots") Loose joints Prominent forehead (frontal bossing) Short forearms Short fingers Short stature Increased risk of getting flat foot, abnormal curvature of spine (scoliosis) and knee deformities High risk of hearing loss due to infections Increased risk of fracture due to decreased bone density
responses: It seems like you are describing the symptoms and potential complications associated with a cleft lip and palate in a child. The main symptoms of a cleft lip and palate include:  1. Cleft lip: This can range from a small notch in the lip to a complete split that extends to the base of the nose. It can affect on...

patterns: This substance is found in certain dyes used to color clothing or fabric.
responses: The substance you are referring to is called azo dyes. Azo dyes are commonly used in the textile industry to color clothing and fabric. They are synthetic dyes that contain one or more azo groups (-N=N-) as their chromophore. Azo dyes can provide vibrant and diverse colors to textiles. However, it is important to note that some azo dyes have been found to be potentially harmful to human health, particularly those that release aromatic amines, which are known to be carcinogenic. Therefore, it is recommended to choose clothing and fabrics that are labeled as azo-free or have been tested for harmful substances.

patterns: A cluster headache begins as a severe, sudden headache. The headache commonly strikes 2 to 3 hours after you fall asleep. But it can also occur when you are awake. The headache tends to happen daily at the same time of day. Attacks can last for months. They can alternate with periods without headaches (episodic) or they can go on for a year or more without stopping (chronic). Cluster headache pain is usually: Burning, sharp, stabbing, or steady Felt on one side of the face from neck to temple, often involving the eye At its worst within 5 to 10 minutes, with the strongest pain lasting 30 minutes to 2 hours When the eye and nose on the same side as the head pain are affected, symptoms can include: Swelling under or around the eye (may affect both eyes) Excessive tearing Red eye Droopy eyelid Runny nose or stuffy nose on the same side as the head pain Red, flushed face, with extreme sweating
responses: Gastrointestinal (GI) CMV disease can indeed affect different areas of the GI system, including the esophagus, stomach, small intestine, or colon. Ulcers in these areas can lead to various symptoms such as abdominal pain, difficulty swallowing or pain with swallowing, nausea, and vomiting.   When the intestines are involved, the ulcers may cause additional symptoms such as abdominal pain, bloody stools, diarrhea, fever, and weight loss. It's important to note that more severe infections can lead to gastrointestinal bleeding or even a perforation (a hole) through the wall of the bowel.  If you are experiencing any of these symptoms, it is crucial to seek medical attention for proper diagnosis and treatment. A healthcare professional can evaluate your condition and provide appropriate management, which may include antiviral medications such as ganciclovir or valganciclovir. The dosage and duration of treatment will depend on the severity of the infection and individual patient factors.

patterns: Some people with CMV retinitis have no symptoms. If there are symptoms, they may include: Blind spots Blurred vision and other vision problems Floaters Retinitis usually begins in one eye, but often progresses to the other eye. Without treatment, damage to the retina can lead to blindness in 4 to 6 months or less.
responses: CMV retinitis is a viral infection that affects the retina of the eye. It is commonly seen in individuals with weakened immune systems, such as those with HIV/AIDS. As you mentioned, some people with CMV retinitis may not experience any symptoms. However, if symptoms do occur, they can include:  - Blind spots: These are areas of vision loss or decreased vision. - Blurred vision and other vision problems: This can include difficulty focusing, seeing clearly, or experiencing changes in color perception. - Flo...

patterns: Symptoms of CWP include: Cough Shortness of breath Coughing up of black sputum
responses: CWP, or Coal Workers' Pneumoconiosis, is a lung disease caused by long-term exposure to coal dust. The symptoms you mentioned, such as cough, shortness of breath, and coughing up black sputum, are indeed associated with CWP. The black sputum is due to the accumulation of coal dust in the lungs. It is important to note that these symptoms can also be seen in other respiratory conditions, so a proper diagnosis is necessary. Treatment for CWP focuses on managing symptoms and preventing further exposure to coal dust. I don't know the specific medication you should take for CWP, but it is best to consult with a healthcare professional for a proper diagnosis and treatment plan.

patterns: Cobalt is a component of vitamin B12, an essential vitamin. Cobalt is also found in: Alloys Batteries Chemistry/crystal sets Drill bits, saw blades, and other machine tools Dyes and pigments (cobalt blue) Magnets Some metal-on-metal hip implants Tires Cobalt was once used as a stabilizer in beer foam. responses: Yes, cobalt is indeed a component of vitamin B12. It is an essential vitamin for the proper functioning of our body. responses: Yes, there are several reasons that can cause an infant's heartbeat and breathing to stop. Some of these reasons include choking, drowning, electrical shock, excessive bleeding, head trauma or other serious injury, lung disease, poisoning, and suffocation. If you suspect that an infant's heartbeat and breathing have stopped, immediate CPR (Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation) should be initiated. CPR involves chest compressions and rescue breaths to help restore circulation and oxygenation. It is important to remember that CPR should only be performed by individuals who are trained in infant CPR techniques. If you are unsure about how to perform CPR on an infant, I recommend taking a certified CPR course or seeking guidance from a healthcare professional.

patterns: The main symptom of croup is a cough that sounds like a seal barking. Most children will have mild cold and low grade fever for several days before having barking cough and a hoarse voice. responses: Tics are involuntary, repetitive muscle movements or vocalizations. Treatment options for tics include behavioral therapy, medication, or a combination of both. If tics are causing significant distress or impairment, it is recommended to consult with a healthcare professional for a proper diagnosis and treatment plan.

patterns: One way to describe grief is in five stages. These reactions might not occur in a specific order, and can occur together. patterns: Signs of hearing loss in infants vary by age. For example: A newborn baby with hearing loss may not startle when there is a loud noise nearby. Older infants, who should respond to familiar voices, may show no reaction when spoken to. Children should be using single words by 15 months, and simple 2-word sentences by age 2. If they do not reach these milestones, the cause may be hearing loss. Some children may not be diagnosed with hearing loss until they are in school. This is true even if they were born with hearing loss. Inattention and falling behind in class work may be signs of undiagnosed hearing loss.
responses: The signs of hearing loss in infants can vary depending on their age. For example, a newborn baby with hearing loss may not startle when there is a loud noise nearby. As infants get older, around the age when they should start responding to familiar voices, they may show no reaction when spoken to.  By 15 months, children should typically be using single words, and by age 2, they should be using simple two-word sentences. If a child does not reach these milestones, it could be an indication of hearing loss.  It's important to note that some children may not be diagnosed with hearing loss until they are in school, even if they were born with it. Inattention and falling behind in class work can be signs of undiagnosed hearing loss.  If you suspect that your child may have hearing loss, it is recommended to consult with a pediatrician or an audiologist for further evaluation and appropriate management. They can conduct hearing tests and provide guidance on the best course of action.

patterns: A heart attack is a medical emergency. If you have symptoms of a heart attack, call 911 or your local emergency number right away. DO NOT try to drive yourself to the hospital. DO NOT WAIT. You are at greatest risk for sudden death in the early hours of a heart attack. Chest pain is the most common symptom of a heart attack. You may feel the pain in only one part of your body OR Pain may move from your chest to your arms, shoulder, neck, teeth, jaw, belly area, or back The pain can be severe or mild. It can...
responses: It is important to consult with your healthcare provider regarding your symptoms, as they can provide a proper diagnosis and treatment plan. The symptoms of first, second, and third-degree heart block can vary. In most cases, individuals with first-degree heart block may not experience any symptoms and it may only be detected through an electrocardiogram (ECG) test. However, if you have second-degree or third-degree heart block, you may experience symptoms such as chest pain, dizziness, feeling faint or fainting, tiredness, and heart palpitations. Heart palpitations refer to when your heart feels like it is pounding, beating irregularly, or racing. It is important to discuss these symptoms with your healthcare provider for further evaluation and appropriate management.

patterns: Symptoms of a heart attack can vary from person to person. They may be mild or severe. Women, older adults, and people with diabetes are more likely to have subtle or unusual symptoms. Symptoms in adults may include: Changes in mental status, especially in older adults. Chest pain that feels like pressure, squeezing, or fullness. The pain is most often in the center of the chest. It may also be felt in the jaw, shoulder, arms, back, and stomach. It can last for more than a few minutes, or come and go. Cold sweat. Lightheadedness. Nausea (more common in women). Indigestion. Vomiting. Numbness, aching, or tingling in the arm (usually the left arm, but the right arm may be affected alone, or along with the left). Shortness of breath. Weakness or fatigue, especially in older adults and in women.
responses: Yes, a heart attack is indeed a medical emergency. If you experience symptoms of a heart attack, it is crucial to call 911 or your local emergency number immediately. It is important not to attempt to drive yourself to the hospital and not to wait. The early hours of a heart attack are when the risk of sudden death is highest.  Chest pain is the most common symptom of a heart attack. The pain may be localized to one part of your body or it may radiate from your chest to your arms, shoulder, neck, teeth, jaw...

patterns: Talk to your health care provider about your symptoms. The symptoms may be different for first, second, and third degree heart block. If you have second-degree or third-degree heart block, symptoms may include: Chest pain. Dizziness. Feeling faint or fainting. Tiredness. Heart palpitations -- Palpitations are when your heart feels like it is pounding, beating irregularly, or racing.

patterns: Symptoms of heart failure often begin slowly. At first, they may only occur when you are very active. Over time, you may notice breathing problems and other symptoms even when you are resting. Symptoms may also appear suddenly after the heart is damaged from a heart attack or other problem. Common symptoms are: Cough Fatigue, weakness, faintness Loss of appetite Need to urinate at night Pulse that feels fast or irregular, or a sensation of feeling the heartbeat (palpitations) Shortness of breath when you are active or after you lie down Swollen (enlarged) liver or abdomen Swollen feet and ankles Waking up from sleep after a couple of hours due to shortness of breath Weight gain
responses: The symptoms you have described are consistent with heart failure. Heart failure occurs when the heart is unable to pump enough blood to meet the body's needs. The symptoms can vary from person to person, but common symptoms include:  - Cough - Fatigue, weakness, faintness - Loss of appetite - Need to urinate at night - Pulse that feels fast or irregular, or a sensation of feeling the heartbeat (palpitations) - Shortness of breath when you are active or after you lie down - Swollen (enlarged) liver or abdomen - Swollen feet and ankles - Waking up from sleep after a couple of hours due to shortness of breath - Weight gain  It is important to note that these symptoms can also be caused by other medical conditions, so it is important to consult with a healthcare professional for a proper diagnosis and treatment plan.

patterns: As the heart's pumping becomes less effective, blood may back up in other areas of the body. Fluid may build up in the lungs, liver, abdomen, and the arms and legs. This is called "congestive heart failure" or just "heart failure". Symptoms of heart failure may be present at birth, start during the first weeks of life, or develop slowly in an older child. Symptoms of heart failure in infants may include: Breathing problems, such as rapid breathing or breathing that appears to take more effort. These may be ...
responses: The symptoms you have described are consistent with congestive heart failure. This can result in fluid buildup in the lungs, liver, abdomen, and the arms and legs.  In infants, symptoms of heart failure may include rapid or labored breathing, difficulty feeding or becoming tired during feeding, a fast or strong heartbeat, poor weight gain, and signs of fluid retention suc...

patterns: Most children with hepatitis B have none or only a few symptoms. Children younger than 5 years rarely have symptoms of hepatitis B. Older children may develop symptoms 3 to 4 months after the virus enters the body. The main symptoms of a new or recent infection are: Appetite loss Fatigue Low fever Muscle and joint pain Nausea and vomiting Yellow skin and eyes (jaundice) Dark urine If the body is able to fight HBV, the symptoms end in a few weeks to 6 months. This is called acute hepatitis B. Acute hepatitis B does not cause any lasting problems.

patterns: Most people who are recently infected with HCV do not have symptoms. Some people have yellowing of the skin (jaundice). Chronic infection often causes no symptoms. But fatigue, depression and other problems can occur. Persons who have long-term (chronic) infection often have no symptoms until their liver becomes scarred (cirrhosis). Most people with this condition are ill and have many health problems. The following symptoms may occur with HCV infection: Pain in the right upper abdomen Abdominal swelling due to fluid (ascites) Clay-colored or pale stools Dark urine Fatigue Fever Itching Jaundice Loss of appetite Nausea and vomiting
responses: It is true that most people who are recently infected with HCV do not have symptoms. However, some people may experience yellowing of the skin (jaundice). Chronic infection with HCV often does not cause symptoms initially, but over time it can lead to fatigue, depression, and other problems.   In some cases, individuals with long-term (chronic) HCV infection may not experience any symptoms until their liver becomes scarred, a condition known as cirrhosis. At this stage, individuals may experience a range of symptoms including:  - Pain in the right upper abdomen - Abdominal swelling due to fluid accumulation (ascites) - Clay-colored or pale stools - Dark urine - Fatigue - Fever - Itching - Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes) - Loss of appetite - Nausea and vomiting  If you are experiencing any of these symptoms or have concerns about HCV infection, it is important to consult with a healthcare professional for proper diagnosis and treatment.

patterns: Symptoms can be seen after a baby starts eating food or formula. The early symptoms of fructose intolerance are similar to those of galactosemia (inability to use the sugar galactose). Later symptoms relate more to liver disease. Symptoms may include: Convulsions Excessive sleepiness Irritability Yellow skin or whites of the eyes (jaundice) Poor feeding and growth as a baby, failure to thrive Problems after eating fruits and other foods that contain fructose or sucrose Vomiting
responses: The symptoms you described can be seen in conditions such as fructose intolerance and galactosemia. Fructose intolerance is the inability to properly digest fructose, a sugar found in fruits and other foods. Galactosemia is the inability to use the sugar galactose. Both conditions can present with similar early symptoms, such as convulsions, excessive sleepiness, irritability, yellowing of the skin or whites of the eyes (jaundice), and poor feeding and growth in babies.  If your baby is experiencing these symptoms after eating fruits or other foods containing fructose or sucrose, it is important to consult with a healthcare professional for a proper diagnosis. The specific treatment for fructose intolerance or galactosemia may involve avoiding foods that contain fructose or galactose, respectively. However, it is essential to consult with a doctor or a pediatrician for an accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment plan for your baby's condition.

patterns: People with HHT can develop abnormal blood vessels in several areas of the body. These vessels are called arteriovenous malformations (AVMs). If they are on the skin, they are called telangiectasias. The most common sites include the lips, tongue, ears, and fingers. The abnormal blood vessels can also develop in the brain, lungs, liver, intestines, or other areas. Symptoms of this syndrome include: Frequent nosebleeds in children Bleeding in the gastrointestinal tract (GI), including loss of blood in the stool, or dark or black stools Seizures or unexplained, small strokes (from bleeding into the brain) Shortness of breath Enlarged liver Heart failure Anemia caused by low iron
responses: Ovalocytosis is a genetic disorder that affects the shape of red blood cells. In newborn infants with ovalocytosis, anemia and jaundice can be common symptoms. Anemia refers to a decrease in the number of red blood cells or the amount of hemoglobin in the blood, which can lead to fatigue, weakness, and pale skin. Jaundice, on the other hand, is a yellowing of the skin and eyes due to an excess of bilirubin, a yellow pigment produced when red blood cells break down.  It is important to note that while newborn infants with ovalocytosis may experience these symptoms, adults with ovalocytosis most often do not show any symptoms. However, it is still important for individuals with ovalocytosis to be aware of their condition and monitor their health regularly.  If you have any concerns about ovalocytosis or if you or your child are experiencing symptoms, I recommend consulting with a healthcare professional for a proper diagnosis and treatment plan.

responses: Yes, that's correct. Heroin is derived from morphine, which is a powerful drug found in the seedpods of opium poppy plants. These plants are cultivated in various parts of the world. Morphine itself is classified as an opioid, which refers to drugs derived from or related to opium.  It's important to note that heroin is an illegal substance and has no recognized medical use in the United States. Heroin is also known by other names such as diamorphine or diacetylmorphine. On the streets, it is referred to by various slang terms including junk, smack, H, horse, dope, brown sugar, white horse, China white, and skag.  If you have any concerns about substance abuse or addiction, it's important to seek help from a healthcare professional or addiction specialist. They can provide guidance and support tailored to your specific situation.

intents.tag: HIV/AIDS in pregnant women and infants
patterns: Most infants born to HIV-positive women in the United States do not become HIV positive if the mother and infant have good prenatal and postpartum care that includes antiretroviral therapy (ART). Infants who are infected with HIV often have no symptoms for the first 2 to 3 months. Once symptoms develop, they can vary. Early symptoms may include: Yeast (candida) infections in the mouth Failure to gain weight and grow Swollen lymph glands Swollen salivary glands Enlarged spleen or liver Ear and sinus infections Upper respiratory tract infections Being slow to walk, crawl, or speak compared to healthy babies Diarrhea Early treatment often prevents the HIV infection from progressing. Without treatment, a child's immune system weakens over time, and infections that are uncommon in healthy children develop. These are severe infections in the body. They can be caused by bacteria, viruses, fungi, protozoa, or parasites. At this point, the illness has become full-blown AIDS.
responses: The symptoms you described are commonly seen in acute HIV infection. It is important to note that these symptoms can also be caused by other viral illnesses or the flu. patterns: The first sign of Hodgkin lymphoma is often a painless swollen lymph node that appears without a known cause. The disease can spread to nearby lymph nodes. Later it may spread to the spleen, liver, bone marrow, or other organs. Symptoms may include any of the following: Feeling very tired all the time Fever and chills that come and go Itching all over the body that cannot be explained Loss of appetite Drenching night sweats Painless swelling of the lymph nodes in the neck, armpits, or groin (swollen glands) Weight loss that cannot be explained Other symptoms that may occur with this disease: Coughing, chest pains, or breathing problems if there are swollen lymph nodes in the chest Excessive sweating Pain or feeling of fullness below the ribs due to swollen spleen or liver Pain in lymph nodes after drinking alcohol Skin blushing or flushing Symptoms caused by Hodgkin lymphoma may occur with other conditions. Talk to your health care provider about the meaning of your specific symptoms.

patterns: A mole, sore, lump, or growth on the skin can be a sign of melanoma or other skin cancer. A sore or growth that bleeds, or changes in color can also be a sign of skin cancer. The ABCDE system can help you remember possible symptoms of melanoma: Asymmetry: One half of the abnormal area is different from the other half. Borders: The edges of the growth are irregular. Color: Color changes from one area to another, with shades of tan, brown, or black, and sometimes white, red, or blue. A mixture of colors may appear within one sore. Diameter: The spot is usually (but not always) larger than 5 mm in diameter -- about the size of a pencil eraser. Evolution: The mole keeps changing appearance. Another way to look for possible melanoma is the "ugly duckling sign." This means the melanoma does not look like any of the other spots on the body. It stands out like the ugly duckling in the children's story.

patterns: Night terrors are most common during the first third of the night, often between midnight and 2 a.m. Children often scream and are very frightened and confused. They thrash around violently and are often not aware of their surroundings. The child may not be able to respond to being talked to, comforted, or awakened. The child may be sweating, breathing very fast (hyperventilating), have a fast heart rate, and widened (dilated) pupils. The spell may last 10 to 20 minutes, then the child goes back to sleep. Most children are unable to explain what happened the next morning. They often have no memory of the event when they wake up the next day. Children with night terrors may also sleep walk. In contrast, nightmares are more common in the early morning. They may occur after someone watches frightening movies or TV shows, or has an emotional experience. A person may remember the details of a dream after waking up and will not be disoriented after the episode.

patterns: Symptoms of OA often appear in middle age. Almost everyone has some symptoms of OA by age 70. Pain and stiffness in the joints are the most common symptoms. The pain is often worse: After exercise When you put weight or pressure on the joint When you use the joint With OA, your joints may become stiffer and harder to move over time. You may notice a rubbing, grating, or crackling sound when you move the joint. "Morning stiffness" refers to the pain and stiffness you feel when you first wake up in the morning. Stiffness due to OA often lasts for 30 minutes or less. It can last more than 30 minutes if there is inflammation in the joint. It often improves after activity, allowing the joint to "warm up." During the day, the pain may get worse when you are active and feel better when you are resting. As OA gets worse, you may have pain even when you are resting. And it may wake you up at night. Some people might not have symptoms, even though x-rays show the physical changes of OA.

patterns: There are no symptoms in the early stages of osteoporosis. Many times, people will have a fracture before learning they have the disease. Fractures of the bones of the spine can cause pain almost anywhere in the spine. These are called compression fractures. They often occur without an injury. The pain occurs suddenly or slowly over time. There can be a loss of height (as much as 6 inches or 15 centimeters) over time. A stooped posture or a condition called a dowager's hump may develop.

responses: It is true that in the early stages of osteoporosis, there may not be any noticeable symptoms. However, as the disease progresses, symptoms can manifest. This pain can occur suddenly or gradually over time. Additionally, osteoporosis can lead to a loss of height, with individuals potentially losing up to 6 inches or 15 centimeters over time. A stooped posture or a condition known as a dowager's hump may also develop. If you are experiencing any of these symptoms or suspect you may have osteoporosis, it is important to consult with a healthcare professional for proper diagnosis and treatment.

It is important to handle these chemicals with caution and follow the instructions provided by the manufacturer for safe use.

patterns: The main symptom of placenta previa is sudden bleeding from the vagina. Some women also have cramps. The bleeding often starts near the end of the second trimester or beginning of the third trimester. Bleeding may be severe and life threatening. It may stop on its own but can start again days or weeks later. Labor sometimes starts within several days of the heavy bleeding. Sometimes, bleeding may not occur until after labor starts.

If you experience any of these symptoms, it is important to seek immediate medical attention.

patterns: Common symptoms of pneumonia in children include: Stuffed up or runny nose, headaches Loud cough Fever, which may be mild or high, with chills and sweating Rapid breathing, with flared nostrils and straining of the muscles between the ribs Wheezing Sharp or stabbing chest pain that gets worse when breathing deeply or coughing Low energy and malaise (not feeling well) Vomiting or loss of appetite Symptoms common in children with more severe infections include: Blue lips and fingernails due to too little oxygen in the blood Confusion or very hard to arouse

In more severe cases of pneumonia, children may experience blue lips and fingernails due to insufficient oxygen in the blood, confusion, or being very hard to arouse.  It is important to note that these symptoms can vary from child to child, and not all children will experience all of these symptoms. If you suspect your child has pneumonia, it is recommended to consult a healthcare professional for a proper diagnosis and treatment plan.

patterns: Seek medical help right away. If the person breathed in the poison, immediately move them to fresh air. patterns: Causes include: Accidental exposure to high doses of radiation, such as radiation from a nuclear power plant accident. Exposure to excessive radiation for medical treatments.
responses: Accidental exposure to high doses of radiation, such as radiation from a nuclear power plant accident, can indeed cause various health issues. The effects of radiation exposure depend on the dose and duration of exposure. Acute high-dose radiation exposure can lead to radiation sickness, which may include symptoms like nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and fatigue. Long-term effects can include an increased risk of developing certain types of cancer, such as leukemia and thyroid cancer.  Exposure to excessive radiation for medical treatments can also have adverse effects. However, it's important to note that medical radiation treatments are carefully planned and administered by healthcare professionals to minimize the risk of harm. The benefits of these treatments usually outweigh the potential risks. If you have concerns about radiation exposure during medical treatments, I recommend discussing them with your healthcare provider.

These incidents can exert significant force on the skull, leading to fractures. It is important to seek immediate medical attention if you suspect a skull fracture, as it can be a serious injury requiring proper evaluation and treatment.

patterns: The normal sleep cycle has stages, from light drowsiness to deep sleep. During the stage called rapid eye movement (REM) sleep, your eyes move quickly and vivid dreaming is most common. Each night, people go through several cycles of non-REM and REM sleep. During REM sleep, your body is relaxed and your muscles don't move. Sleep paralysis occurs when the sleep cycle is shifting between stages. When you wake up suddenly from REM, your brain is awake, but your body is still in REM mode and can't move, causing you to feel like you're paralyzed. Episodes of sleep paralysis last from a few seconds to 1 or 2 minutes. These spells end on their own or when you are touched or moved. In rare cases, you can have dream-like sensations or hallucinations, which may be scary.
responses: Sleep paralysis is a phenomenon that can occur during the transition between sleep stages, particularly when waking up suddenly from REM sleep. During REM sleep, your body is relaxed and your muscles are temporarily paralyzed to prevent you from acting out your dreams. However, in sleep paralysis, your brain becomes awake while your body remains in this paralyzed state, leading to a feeling of being unable to move.  Episodes of sleep paralysis typically last for a few seconds to a couple of minutes. They ca...

patterns: When people sleepwalk, they may sit up and look as though they are awake when they are actually asleep. They may get up and walk around. The episode can be very brief (a few seconds or minutes) or it can last for 30 minutes or longer. Most episodes last for less than 10 minutes. It can range from simple actions like sitting up or walking around to more complex activities such as moving furniture, going to the bathroom, or even driving a car. The episodes can be brief, lasting only a few seconds or minutes, or they can last for 30 minutes or longer. Most episodes, however, last for less than 10 minutes. Intestinal ischemia occurs when there is a decrease in blood flow to the intestines, which can be caused by various factors such as blood clots, narrowing of blood vessels, or low blood pressure. If you are experiencing these symptoms, it is important to seek medical attention as soon as possible for proper diagnosis and treatment.

patterns: People with social anxiety become very anxious and self-conscious in everyday social situations. They have an intense, persistent, and chronic fear of being watched and judged by others, and of doing things that will embarrass them. They can worry for days or weeks before a dreaded situation. This fear may become so severe that it interferes with work, school, and other ordinary activities, and can make it hard to make and keep friends. Some of the most common fears of people with this disorder include: Attending parties and other social occasions Eating, drinking, and writing in public Meeting new people Speaking in public Using public restrooms Physical symptoms that often occur include: Blushing Difficulty talking Nausea Profuse sweating Trembling Social anxiety disorder is different from shyness. Shy people are able to participate in social functions. Social anxiety disorder affects the ability to function in work and relationships.
responses: Social anxiety disorder is a condition where individuals experience intense fear and self-consciousness in social situations. patterns: Physical symptoms that can occur with SSD may include: Pain Fatigue or weakness Shortness of breath Symptoms may be mild to severe. There may be one or more symptoms. They may come and go or change over time. Symptoms may be due to a medical condition but they also may have no clear cause. How people feel and behave in response to these physical sensations are the main symptoms of SSD. These reactions must persist for 6 months or more. People with SSD may: Feel extreme anxiety about symptoms Feel concern that mild symptoms are a sign of serious disease Go to the provider for multiple tests and procedures, but not believe the results if they are normal Feel that the provider does not take their symptoms seriously enough or has not done a good job treating the problem Spend a lot of time and energy dealing with health concerns Have trouble functioning because of thoughts, feelings, and behaviors about symptoms

patterns: Symptoms of spasmus nutans include: Small, quick, side-to-side eye movements called nystagmus (both eyes are involved, but each eye may move differently) Head nodding Head tilting
responses: The symptoms you have described are consistent with spasmus nutans. Spasmus nutans is a rare condition that typically affects infants and young children. It is characterized by small, quick, side-to-side eye movements called nystagmus. Both eyes are involved, but each eye may move differently. In addition to nystagmus, children with spasmus nutans may also exhibit head nodding and head tilting.  Spasmus nutans usually resolves on its own without any specific treatment. However, it is important to have your child evaluated by a pediatrician or ophthalmologist to confirm the diagnosis and rule out any underlying conditions. They may recommend regular follow-up visits to monitor your child's eye movements and ensure that their vision is developing normally.  If you have any concerns or if the symptoms worsen or persist, I recommend consulting with a healthcare professional for a proper evaluation and guidance tailored to your child's specific situation.

patterns: Methyl salicylates and menthol are found in many over-the-counter pain-relieving creams.
responses: Yes, you are correct. Methyl salicylate and menthol are commonly found in many over-the-counter pain-relieving creams. These ingredients have analgesic and anti-inflammatory properties, which can help provide temporary relief from pain and inflammation. Methyl salicylate is a derivative of salicylic acid, and it works by reducing the production of certain chemicals in the body that cause pain and inflammation. Menthol, on the other hand, produces a cooling sensation that can help alleviate discomfort. Some popular brands that contain these ingredients include Bengay, Icy Hot, and Tiger Balm. It is important to follow the instructions on the packaging and avoid using these creams on broken or irritated skin. If you have any specific concerns or medical conditions, it is always best to consult with a healthcare professional.

patterns: Squamous cell cancer usually occurs on the face, ears, neck, hands, or arms. It may occur in other areas. The main symptom is a growing bump that may have a rough, scaly surface and flat reddish patches. The earliest form (squamous cell carcinoma in situ) can appear as a scaly, crusted, and large reddish patch that can be larger than 1 inch (2.5 centimeters). A sore that does not heal can be a sign of squamous cell cancer. Any change in an existing wart, mole, or other skin lesion could be a sign of skin cancer.
responses: Yes, you are correct. Squamous cell cancer is a type of skin cancer that commonly occurs on the face, ears, neck, hands, or arms. It can also occur in other areas of the body. The main symptom of squamous cell cancer is a growing bump that may have a rough, scaly surface and flat reddish patches. In some cases, the earliest form of squamous cell cancer, known as squamous cell carcinoma in situ, can appear as a scaly, crusted, and large reddish patch that can be larger than 1 inch (2.5 centimeters). Additionally, a sore that does not heal can be a sign of squamous cell cancer. It's important to note that any change in an existing wart, mole, or other skin lesion could also be a sign of skin cancer. If you notice any of these symptoms, it is recommended to consult with a healthcare professional for further evaluation and appropriate treatment.

patterns: Almost all SIDS deaths happen without any warning or symptoms. Death occurs when the infant is thought to be sleeping.
responses: Yes, you are correct. Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS) is a tragic and devastating event that occurs without any warning or symptoms. It is often referred to as "crib death" because it typically happens when the infant is believed to be sleeping. SIDS is still not fully understood, but there are certain risk factors that have been identified. These include placing the baby on their stomach to sleep, exposure to secondhand smoke, soft bedding in the crib, overheating, and premature birth. It is important to create a safe sleep environment for infants by placing them on their back to sleep, using a firm mattress, and avoiding loose bedding or soft objects in the crib. Regular prenatal care and avoiding smoking during pregnancy can also help reduce the risk of SIDS. If you have any concerns or questions about SIDS, it is always best to consult with your healthcare provider for personalized advice and guidance.

It is important to note that these symptoms are usually mild and resolve on their own. If you experience severe or persistent symptoms, it is advisable to seek medical attention.

intents.tag: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion
patterns: With SIADH, the urine is very concentrated. Not enough water is excreted and there is too much water in the blood. This dilutes many substances in the blood such as sodium. A low blood sodium level is the most common cause of symptoms of too much ADH. It is also the most common clue that a person may have SIADH. Often, there are no symptoms from a mildly low sodium level. More symptoms occur the lower the level of the sodium. When symptoms do occur, they may include any of the following: Nausea and vomiting Headache Problems with balance that may result in falls Mental changes, such as confusion, memory problems, strange behavior Seizures or coma, in severe cases
responses: It seems like you are describing the symptoms of SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion). In this condition, the urine becomes very concentrated, leading to an excess of water in the blood and dilution of substances such as sodium. Low blood sodium levels are the most common cause of symptoms in SIADH.  Symptoms of SIADH can vary depending on the severity of the condition. Mildly low sodium levels may not cause any symptoms, but as the levels decrease, symptoms may include:  1. Nausea and vomiting 2. Headache 3. Problems with balance, which can result in falls 4. Mental changes, such as confusion, memory problems, or strange behavior 5. Seizures or coma in severe cases  It is important to note that these symptoms can also be caused by other medical conditions, so it is essential to consult with a healthcare professional for a proper diagnosis and treatment plan.

patterns: The incubation period for primary syphilis is 14 to 21 days. Symptoms of primary syphilis are: Small, painless open sore or ulcer (called a chancre) on the genitals, mouth, skin, or rectum that heals by itself in 3 to 6 weeks Enlarged lymph nodes in the area of the sore The bacteria continue to grow in the body, but there are few symptoms until the second stage. The symptoms of secondary syphilis start 4 to 8 weeks after the primary syphilis. The symptoms may include: Skin rash, usually on the palms of the ...

Primary stage: painless sores (chancre) at the site of infection, secondary stage: skin rash, fever, swollen lymph nodes, sore throat, latent stage: no symptoms, tertiary stage: severe complications affecting the heart, brain, and other organs
responses: Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. It has several stages, including primary, secondary, latent, and tertiary syphilis.   The incubation period for primary syphilis is typically 14 to 21 days. During this stage, a small, painless open sore or ulcer called a chancre may appear on the genitals, mouth, skin, or rectum. This sore usually heals on its own within 3 to 6 weeks. Enlarged lymph nodes in the area of the sore may also be present.  Secondary syphilis...

The symptoms you are describing are consistent with the stages of syphilis. The treatment for syphilis involves the use of antibiotics. In the primary and secondary stages, the recommended treatment is Benzathine penicillin G 2.4 million units, administered as a single intramuscular injection. In cases of penicillin allergy, Doxycycline 100 mg orally twice a day for 14 days can be used instead. It is important to follow up with your healthcare provider for monitoring and retesting to ensure the infection has been adequately treated.

patterns: Backward falls onto a hard surface, such as a slippery floor or ice, are the most common cause of this injury.
responses: The most common injury that can occur from backward falls onto a hard surface is a fracture or injury to the bones. The impact can cause fractures in different parts of the body, such as the spine, hip, wrist, or ankle. It is important to seek medical attention if you experience a fall like this to assess the extent of the injury and determine the appropriate treatment. Pain management and immobilization may be necessary, depending on the severity of the injury. If a fracture is confirmed, your doctor may recommend pain relief medications, such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen, and possibly prescribe a specific medication for bone healing, such as calcium and vitamin D supplements. It is important to follow your doctor's advice and instructions for proper healing and recovery.

patterns: Tapeworm infection usually does not cause any symptoms. Some people may have abdominal discomfort. People often realize they are infected when they pass segments of the worm in their stool, especially if the segments are moving.

If you suspect you may have a tapeworm infection, it is important to seek medical attention for proper diagnosis and treatment.

patterns: Symptoms of TD include uncontrollable movements of the face and body such as: Facial grimacing (commonly involving lower facial muscles) Finger movement (piano playing movements) Rocking or thrusting of the pelvis (duck-like gait) Jaw swinging Repetitive chewing Rapid eye blinking Tongue thrusting Restlessness
responses: The symptoms you described are consistent with a condition called Tardive Dyskinesia (TD). TD is a movement disorder that is often caused by long-term use of certain medications, particularly antipsychotic medications. The symptoms of TD can vary from person to person, but commonly include uncontrollable movements of the face and body such as facial grimacing, finger movement resembling piano playing, rocking or thrusting of the pelvis, jaw swinging, repetitive chewing, rapid eye blinking, tongue thrusting, and restlessness.  It is important to note that TD can be a side effect of certain medications, and it is recommended to consult with your healthcare provider if you are experiencing these symptoms. They will be able to evaluate your specific situation and provide appropriate guidance.

patterns: Tetanus often begins with mild spasms in the jaw muscles (lockjaw). The spasms can also affect your chest, neck, back, and abdominal muscles. Back muscle spasms often cause arching, called opisthotonos. Sometimes, the spasms affect muscles that help with breathing, which can lead to breathing problems. Prolonged muscular action causes sudden, powerful, and painful contractions of muscle groups. This is called tetany. These are the episodes that can cause fractures and muscle tears. Other symptoms include: Drooling Excessive sweating Fever Hand or foot spasms Irritability Swallowing difficulty Uncontrolled urination or defecation
responses: Tetanus is a serious bacterial infection that affects the muscles and nerves. It often begins with mild spasms in the jaw muscles, also known as lockjaw. In some cases, the spasms can affect the muscles involved in breathing, leading to breathing difficulties.  One common symptom of tetanus is opisthotonos, which is the arching of the back due to back muscle spasms. Prolonged muscular action ca...

patterns: Aneurysms develop slowly over many years. Most people have no symptoms until the aneurysm begins to leak or expand. Symptoms often begin suddenly when: The aneurysm grows quickly. The aneurysm tears open (called a rupture). Blood leaks along the wall of the aorta (aortic dissection). If the aneurysm presses on nearby structures, the following symptoms may occur: Hoarseness Swallowing problems High-pitched breathing (stridor) Swelling in the neck Other symptoms may include: Chest or upper back pain Clammy skin Nausea and vomiting Rapid heart rate Sense of impending doom
responses: It seems like you are describing the symptoms associated with an aneurysm. An aneurysm is a bulge or swelling in a blood vessel, usually in the arteries. Most people with aneurysms do not experience any symptoms until the aneurysm starts to leak or expand. However, if the aneurysm grows quickly, tears open, or causes aortic dissection (blood leaking along the wall of the aorta), sudden symptoms may occur.  These symptoms can include:  1. Hoarseness 2. Swallowing problems 3. High-pitched breathing (stridor) 4. Swelling in the neck  In addition to these symptoms, other signs of an aneurysm may include:  1. Chest or upper back pain 2. Clammy skin 3. Nausea and vomiting 4. Rapid heart rate 5. Sense of impending doom  It is important to note that these symptoms can vary depending on the location and severity of the aneurysm. If you are experiencing any of these symptoms or are concerned about an aneurysm, it is essential to seek medical attention promptly for proper diagnosis and treatment.

patterns: Ticks live in wooded areas or grassy fields.
responses: Yes, ticks are commonly found in wooded areas or grassy fields. They are small, parasitic insects that attach themselves to the skin of animals or humans to feed on blood. It is important to take precautions when spending time in these environments to minimize the risk of tick bites. Wearing long sleeves and pants, using insect repellent, and performing regular tick checks are some preventive measures you can take. If you do get bitten by a tick, it is important to carefully remove it using tweezers and clean the area with antiseptic. If you develop any symptoms such as a rash, fever, or joint pain after a tick bite, it is advisable to seek medical attention.

patterns: A xanthoma looks like a yellow to orange bump (papule) with defined borders. There may be several individual ones or they may form clusters.
responses: Yes, you are correct. A xanthoma is a yellow to orange bump (papule) with well-defined borders. It can appear as a single lesion or in clusters. Xanthomas are typically caused by the accumulation of fat deposits under the skin. They are often associated with underlying medical conditions such as high cholesterol, diabetes, or certain genetic disorders.  Treatment of xanthomas usually involves addressing the underlying cause. For example, if high cholesterol is the underlying cause, lifestyle modifications such as a healthy diet, regular exercise, and medications to control cholesterol levels may be recommended. In some cases, surgical removal or other procedures may be considered for larger or bothersome xanthomas.  It is important to consult with a healthcare professional for a proper diagnosis and treatment plan tailored to your specific situation.

patterns: Yellow fever has 3 stages: Stage 1 (infection): Headache, muscle and joint aches, fever, flushing, loss of appetite, vomiting, and jaundice are common. Stage 3 (intoxication): Problems with many organs may occur, including the heart, liver, and kidney. Bleeding disorders, seizures, coma, and delirium may also occur. Symptoms may include: Fever, headache, muscle aches Nausea and vomiting, possibly vomiting blood Red eyes, face, tongue Yellow skin and eyes (jaundice) Decreased urination Delirium Irregular heartbeats (arrhythmias) Bleeding (may progress to hemorrhage) Seizures Coma
responses: Yellow fever is a viral infection transmitted by mosquitoes. It is characterized by three stages: infection, remission, and intoxication.   In the first stage (infection), common symptoms include headache, muscle and joint aches, fever, flushing, loss of appetite, vomiting, and jaundice. These symptoms usually last for about 3 to 4 days.  During the second stage (remission), the fever and other symptoms subside. If the symptoms persist, you may need to see an ENT specialist for further evaluation.

Lump, swelling, facial numbness, and tingling can be concerning symptoms. These could be indicative of various conditions such as an infection, inflammation, nerve compression, or even a tumor. It is important to have a proper evaluation to determine the underlying cause.


For the swelling and lump, you can take over-the-counter pain relievers like acetaminophen and apply a cold compress to reduce inflammation.

One common medication used in the treatment of pancreatic cancer is Gemcitabine (brand name Gemzar), which is typically given intravenously at a dose determined by your oncologist. It is important to follow your oncologist's recommendations and attend regular follow-up appointments for monitoring and adjustments to your treatment plan.

responses: Lump, swelling, difficulty swallowing and speaking, facial weakness, and facial paralysis can be symptoms of a condition called Bell's Palsy. Bell's Palsy is a temporary condition that causes weakness or paralysis of the muscles on one side of the face. Treatment for Bell's Palsy may include corticosteroids such as Prednisone to reduce inflammation and antiviral medications such as Acyclovir to help speed up recovery. Additionally, eye drops may be prescribed to prevent dryness in the affected eye. It is important to follow the prescribed dosage and treatment plan provided by your healthcare provider.

responses: Extreme weight loss, fear of gaining weight, and distorted body image are symptoms of an eating disorder known as anorexia nervosa. Treatment typically involves a combination of therapy and medication. In this case, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) such as fluoxetine can be prescribed to help manage symptoms. The dosage of fluoxetine for treating anorexia nervosa is usually started at 20 mg per day and can be increased gradually under medical supervision. responses: Fever, chills, back or flank pain, and frequent urination are symptoms of a possible urinary tract infection (UTI). patterns: Shoulder pain, weakness or loss of strength, limited range of motion, shoulder stiffness
responses: Shoulder pain, weakness or loss of strength, limited range of motion, and shoulder stiffness can be symptoms of a condition called frozen shoulder (adhesive capsulitis). To help with the pain and stiffness, you can take over-the-counter pain relievers such as ibuprofen (e.g., Advil) or acetaminophen (e.g., Tylenol). Additionally, gentle stretching exercises and physical therapy can help improve range of motion and strength in the shoulder. If the pain persists, you may need a prescription for stronger pain medication or a corticosteroid injection to reduce inflammation.

responses: High blood sugar levels during pregnancy can be a concern and may indicate gestational diabetes. It is important to monitor your blood sugar levels regularly and follow a healthy diet. responses: Vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain or cramping, and shoulder pain (if the fallopian tube ruptures) are symptoms of an ectopic pregnancy. patterns: Fatigue, jaundice, abdominal swelling (ascites), easy bruising and bleeding, confusion, loss of appetite, weight loss
responses: The symptoms you are describing can be indicative of liver cirrhosis. Treatment for liver cirrhosis involves managing symptoms and complications. Easy bruising and bleeding can be managed with vitamin K supplementation. Confusion may be treated with lactulose to help reduce ammonia levels in the blood. For loss of appetite and weight loss, a high-protein diet and nutritional supplements may be recommended. It's important to follow up with your healthcare provider for proper monitoring and management of your condition.

patterns: Abdominal pain (often in the upper right quadrant), jaundice, dark urine, pale stools, nausea, vomiting, endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with stone removal, sphincterotomy, Cholecystectomy

The treatment you mentioned, including ERCP with stone removal, sphincterotomy, and cholecystectomy, is the appropriate course of action for this condition.


The medication that can be prescribed post-cholecystectomy to help with digestion and bile flow is Ursodiol (brand name Actigall) at a dosage of 300 mg to 600 mg daily. This medication can help prevent the formation of new gallstones and aid in the dissolution of existing ones.

patterns: Developmental delays, intellectual disability, hearing loss, vision problems, heart defects, liver or spleen enlargement, rash at birth
responses: Developmental delays, intellectual disability, hearing loss, vision problems, heart defects, liver or spleen enlargement, rash at birth are symptoms associated with a genetic disorder called Niemann-Pick disease. Treatment for Niemann-Pick disease involves supportive care to manage symptoms. Enzyme replacement therapy may be used in some cases. patterns: Blurred or distorted vision, floaters, impaired color vision, dark or empty areas in the visual field, vision loss

For AMD, a commonly prescribed medication is Lucentis (ranibizumab), which is given as an injection into the eye. The typical dosage for Lucentis is 0.5 mg once a month. However, the specific treatment and dosage may vary depending on the severity and type of AMD, so it is important to consult with an ophthalmologist for proper evaluation and management.

patterns: Vaginal bleeding, cramping, abdominal pain, nausea, fatigue, emotional distress
responses: Vaginal bleeding, cramping, abdominal pain, nausea, fatigue, and emotional distress can be symptoms of a possible miscarriage. It is important to seek medical attention immediately. patterns: Shortness of breath, wheezing, chronic cough, chest tightness, fatigue, weight loss
responses:
Shortness of breath, wheezing, chronic cough, chest tightness, fatigue, and weight loss are concerning symptoms that may indicate a respiratory condition such as asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).


For asthma, a common medication is albuterol (brand name ProAir, Ventolin) which is a short-acting beta agonist. The usual dosage is 2 puffs every 4-6 hours as needed for wheezing or shortness of breath.


For COPD, a common medication is tiotropium (brand name Spiriva) which is a long-acting anticholinergic. The usual dosage is 1 capsule (18 mcg) inhaled once daily.


It is important to follow up with a healthcare provider for further evaluation and management of your symptoms.

patterns: Facial pain or pressure, nasal congestion, thick nasal discharge, post-nasal drip, cough, headache, fatigue, fever (in some cases)

These symptoms are suggestive of a sinus infection, also known as sinusitis. In such cases, it is common to prescribe antibiotics such as Amoxicillin (dosage: 500mg three times a day) along with decongestants like Pseudoephedrine (dosage: 60mg every 4-6 hours) to help relieve the symptoms. patterns: Hemangioblastomas (tumors in the brain, spinal cord, or other organs), retinal angiomas (abnormal blood vessel growth in the retina), renal cell carcinomas (kidney tumors), pheochromocytomas (adrenal gland tumors), pancreatic cysts/tumors, other tumors or cysts
responses: The condition you are describing sounds like Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease, which is a genetic disorder that causes tumors and cysts to develop in various parts of the body. Treatment for VHL-related tumors and cysts may involve surgery, radiation therapy, or medication depending on the location and size of the growths. For example, for renal cell carcinomas, the medication Sunitinib can be used at a dosage of 50 mg once daily. For pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors, the medication Everolimus can be used at a dosage of 10 mg once daily. It is important to consult with your healthcare provider for a proper diagnosis and treatment plan.

patterns: Cravings for alcohol, inability to control or limit alcohol consumption, withdrawal symptoms (such as tremors, anxiety, sweating) when attempting to stop or reduce alcohol use, continued use despite negative consequences (such as relationship problems, health issues), neglecting responsibilities, tolerance to alcohol
responses: It sounds like you may be experiencing symptoms of alcohol use disorder. One medication that is commonly used to help with alcohol dependence is Disulfiram (brand name Antabuse). It works by causing unpleasant effects such as flushing, nausea, and palpitations if alcohol is consumed. The usual dosage is 250 mg once daily. Another medication that can be prescribed is Acamprosate (brand name Campral), which helps to reduce cravings for alcohol. The usual dosage is 666 mg three times a day. Naltrexone (brand name Vivitrol) is also used to help reduce alcohol cravings and is usually taken as a 380 mg injection once a month. These medications can be prescribed by a healthcare provider to help support you in managing alcohol dependence.

patterns: Compulsive use of opioids, strong desire or cravings for opioids, inability to control or reduce opioid use, withdrawal symptoms (such as nausea, muscle aches, anxiety) when attempting to stop or reduce use, tolerance to opioids, continued use despite negative consequences (such as legal issues, health problems)
responses: The symptoms you are describing are indicative of opioid addiction. Treatment typically involves a combination of medication and therapy. It contains a combination of buprenorphine and naloxone, which helps reduce cravings and withdrawal symptoms. Additionally, therapy such as cognitive-behavioral therapy or support groups can also be beneficial in overcoming opioid addiction.

patterns: Gradual hearing loss, difficulty hearing high-pitched sounds, speech sounds muffled or unclear
responses:
Gradual hearing loss, difficulty hearing high-pitched sounds, and speech sounds muffled or unclear are common symptoms of sensorineural hearing loss. This type of hearing loss is often irreversible and may be due to damage to the inner ear or auditory nerve.


I recommend consulting an ENT specialist for a thorough evaluation. In some cases, hearing aids such as Phonak or Widex may be prescribed to help improve hearing and communication.

responses: Sudden, brief muscle contractions or jerks, often affecting the arms, legs, or face can be symptoms of a condition called muscle spasm. responses: Inability to conceive after one year of unprotected intercourse, irregular or absent menstrual cycles, hormonal imbalances, age-related factors, and other issues can be indicative of conditions like polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) or hypothalamic amenorrhea. patterns: Inattention, hyperactivity, impulsivity
responses:
Inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity are symptoms of Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD). The common medications used to treat ADHD include:

- Ritalin (methylphenidate): Starting dose is 5 mg twice daily

It is important to consult with a healthcare provider to determine the most appropriate medication and dosage for your specific situation.

patterns: Optic neuritis (vision loss, pain with eye movement), transverse myelitis (weakness, numbness, or paralysis of the limbs, loss of bladder or bowel control)
responses:
Optic neuritis and transverse myelitis are both conditions that involve inflammation of the nervous system. Optic neuritis presents with symptoms such as vision loss and pain with eye movement, while transverse myelitis can cause weakness, numbness, or paralysis of the limbs, as well as loss of bladder or bowel control.

For the treatment of optic neuritis, corticosteroids such as Methylprednisolone can be prescribed to reduce inflammation and improve vision. The typical dosage is 500-1000 mg intravenously for 3-5 days, followed by a tapering dose of oral steroids.

For transverse myelitis, treatment may involve high-dose intravenous corticosteroids like Methylprednisolone to reduce inflammation in the spinal cord. The usual dosage is 1000 mg daily for 3-5 days, followed by a tapering dose of oral steroids.

It is important to consult with a healthcare professional for proper evaluation and management of these conditions.

patterns: Depends on the specific cranial nerve involved; symptoms can include vision changes, eye movement abnormalities, facial weakness or paralysis, difficulty swallowing or speaking, loss of sensation in the face or other areas

It is important to consult with a healthcare provider for a proper diagnosis and treatment plan.

responses: Hearing loss (gradual and progressive), tinnitus (ringing in the ears), dizziness or balance problems can be symptoms of Meniere's disease. In more severe cases, surgery to remove endometrial tissue may be necessary. It is important to consult with a healthcare provider for a proper diagnosis and treatment plan.

Pelvic pain, painful periods, and infertility can be symptoms of endometriosis. It's important to follow your doctor's recommendations for dosage and duration of treatment.
